form.longName: PhenX PX210801 - Neighborhood Collective Efficacy Community Cohesion An
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 10 Likert-style, interviewer-administered questions from the Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods (PHDCN). The Social Cohesion and Informal Social Control subscales include five items each.

headerInstruction.text: The following statements are about things that people in your neighborhood may or may not do. For each of these statements, please tell me whether you strongly agree, agree, disagree or strongly disagree.

module.longName: Neighborhood Collective Efficacy - Community Cohesion and Informal Social Control
module.preferredDefinition: Neighborhood Collective Efficacy - Community Cohesion and Informal Social Control

question.questionText: This is a closeknit neighborhood. (close_knit_neighborhood)
People around here are willing to help their neighbors. (people_help_neighbors)
People in this neighborhood generally don't get along with each other. (people_dont_get_along)
People in this neighborhood do not share the same values. (people_donot_share_same_values)
People in this neighborhood can be trusted. (people_can_be_trusted)
For each of the following, please tell me if it is very likely, likely, unlikely or very unlikely that people in your neighborhood would act in the following manner. (instructions_2)

If a group of neighborhood children were skipping school and hanging out on a street corner, how likely is that your neighbors would do something about it? (neighbors_report_children_on_streetcorners)
If some children were spraypainting graffiti on a local building, how likely is it that your neighbors would do something about it? (neighbors_report_children_painting_graffiti)
If a child was showing disrespect to an adult, how likely is it that people in your neighborhood would scold that child? (neighbors_scold_child_showing_disrespect)
If there was a fight in front of your house and someone was being beaten or threatened, how likely is it that your neighbors would break it up? (neighbors_break_up_fight)

Suppose that because of budget cuts the fire station closest to your home was going to be closed down by the city. How likely is it that neighborhood residents would organize to try to do something to keep the fire station open? (neighbors_keep_station_open)

protocol.longName: Neighborhood Collective Efficacy - Community Cohesion and Informal Social Control
protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 10 Likert-style, interviewer-administered questions from the Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods (PHDCN). The Social Cohesion and Informal Social Control subscales include five items each.

form.preferredDefinition: The Mujahid et al. (2007) protocol includes three interviewer-administered questions with five-point, Likert-style responses. The respondent reviews the list of items and chooses the answer that best relates to his or her situation.

question.questionText: I feel safe walking in my neighborhood, day or night. (feel_safe_walking_neighborhood)
Violence is not a problem in my neighborhood. (neighborhood_violence)
My neighborhood is safe from crime. (neighborhood_safe_from_crime)
Scoring Instructions: A total score can be obtained by computing the average of the three items. Lower scores indicate more neighborhood safety. (scoring_210901)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Mujahid et al. (2007) protocol includes three interviewer-administered questions with five-point, Likert-style responses. The respondent reviews the list of items and chooses the answer that best relates to his or her situation.

form.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes 39 self-administered questions developed by Zullig et al. (2010). The items are scored with a five-point Likert scale, from strongly disagree to strongly agree, and include eight subscales: teacher relationships, school connectedness, academic support, order and discipline, school physical environment, school social environment, perceived exclusion/privilege, and academic satisfaction. The respondent reviews a list of items and chooses the answer that best relates to herself or himself.

question.questionText: Teachers understand my problems (teacher_understands_problems)
Teachers and staff seem to take a real interest in my future (teacher_interested_in_future)
Teachers are available when I need to talk with them (teachers_available_to_talk)
It is easy to talk with teachers (easy_to_talk_with_teachers)
Students get along well with teachers (students_get_along_with_teachers)
At my school, there is a teacher or some other adult who notices when I'm not there (teachers_notice_truancy)
Teachers at my school help us children with our problems (teachers_help_with_problems)
My teachers care about me (teachers_care)
My teacher makes me feel good about myself (teachers_feel_good)
My schoolwork is exciting (exciting_schoolwork)
Students can make suggestions on courses that are offered (students_influence_offered_courses)
Students are publicly recognized for their outstanding performances in speech, drama, art, music, etc. (students_recognized_for_arts)
If this school had an extra period during the day, I would take an additional academic class (take_additional_classes)
This school makes students enthusiastic about learning (schools_makes_students_enthusiastic)
Students are frequently rewarded or praised by faculty and staff for following school rules (students_recognized_for_following_rules)
I usually understand my homework assignments (understand_homework)
Teachers make it clear what work needs to be done to get the grade I want (clear_expectations_for_grades)
I believe that teachers expect all students to learn (teachers_expect_students_to_learn)
I feel that I can do well in this school (do_well_in_school)
My teachers believe that I can do well in my school work (teachers_believe_in_students_abilities)
I try hard to succeed in my classes (try_to_succeed)
Classroom rules are applied equally (classroom_rules_applied_equally)
Problems in this school are solved by students and staff (problems_solved_by_staff_students)
Students get in trouble if they do not follow school rules (students_punished_not_following_rules)
The rules of the school are fair (school_rules_are_fair)
School rules are enforced consistently and fairly (school_rules_enforced_fairly_consistently)
My teachers make it clear to me when I have misbehaved in class (teachers_call_out_class_misbehavior)
Discipline is fair (discipline_is_fair)
The school grounds are kept clean (school_grounds_kept_clean)
My school is neat and clean (school_neat_clean)
My school buildings are generally pleasant and well maintained (school_buildings_pleasant_maintained)
My school is usually clean and tidy (school_usually_clean_tidy)
I am happy with kinds of students who go to my school (happy_with_kinds_of_schoolmates)
I am happy, in general, with the other students who go to my school (happy_with_other_students)
At my school, the same person always gets to help the teacher (same_person_helps_teacher)
At my school, the same kids get chosen every time to take part in afterschool or special activities (same_kids_chosen_special_activities)
The same kids always get to use things, like a computer, a ball or a piano, when we play (same_kids_use_resources)
I am happy about the number of tests I have (happy_about_number_tests)
I am happy about the amount of homework I have (happy_about_amount_of_homework)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The protocol includes 39 self-administered questions developed by Zullig et al. (2010). The items are scored with a five-point Likert scale, from strongly disagree to strongly agree, and include eight subscales: teacher relationships, school connectedness, academic support, order and discipline, school physical environment, school social environment, perceived exclusion/privilege, and academic satisfaction. The respondent reviews a list of items and chooses the answer that best relates to herself or himself.
